abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Telecommunications Project in
            Venezuela (Loan 770-VE) was part of a long-term plan of
            telecommunications development, and its aim was to extend
            and improve national and international telecommunications
            services. Compania Anonima Nacional de Telefonos de
            Venezuela (CANTV), the provider of telecommunications
            services in Venezuela, as well as a wholly Government-owned
            utility, is satisfied with the quality and the efficiency of
            the plant obtained with Bank funds through contractors. The
            project has generally achieved, though with some delay, the
            physical growth targets, and less so the institutional
            improvements envisaged at the time of appraisal. The large
            unsatisfied demand for telecommunications services, the
            improved quality of service during the project period and
            the substantial decrease in real terms of tariff levels,
            indicate the existence of a consumer surplus. Assuming
            CANTV's subscribers are willing to pay the same tariffs
            in real terms as they were paying in 1973, the economic rate
            of return on the investment program is estimated at 27
            percent. Several conclusions were drawn from the experiences
            of this project. Changes in personnel and organization of a
            rapidly expanding entity are inevitable. During the period
            of the project, several changes in top management occurred.
            Bank project staff should also carefully monitor project
            progress reports both for their timely receipt and for their
            contents. If borrowers are slack in submission of the
            reports, the Bank should send regular reminders. In 1980
            CANTV became less interested in using the remaining US$5.8
            million of Bank loan funds due to the findings of a study
            based on the 1978-79 experience, when CANTV found itself
            with several sources of investment capital, which due to
            exchange losses on the Bank loan accumulated up to that
            time, was less costly than Bank funds. The Bank should have
            pushed CANTV to review the loan allocation and to recommend
            use of the surplus funds by either preparing proposals for
            procurement of other goods and for their utilization, or to
            insist that the loan should be closed. Finally, if the Bank
            wants to exert sufficient leverage in improving the
            borrowers institutional performance, its contribution should
            be a larger part of the program costs.
